Stretching Molecule Tutorial

Attention

To use the sith tools described in this tutorial, make sure to import Gaussian as explained in Load-modules.

In this tutorial, we will stretch a glycine amino acid capped with ACE and NME groups. The stretching is applied between the terminal carbon atoms of the peptide, until a bond rupture occurs (Figure 1).

The stretching process works as follows:

  1. Optimize the structure without any constraints.

  2. Increase the distance between two selected atoms.

  3. Fix that distance as a constraint.

  4. Re-optimize the structure.

  5. Repeat the process with the optimized configuration from step 1.

At each stretching step, we compute the forces acting on selected internal degrees of freedom. These forces are then used to calculate the distribution of energies.

Prepare Your System

Before stretching, identify your molecule and select the atoms to pull apart. In this example, we use a glycine capped with ACE and NME groups.

For stretching, we select the carbon atoms from the methyl groups at both capping ends (Figure 2). Using a molecular visualization tool, you can check their atom indices (1-based indexing). Here, the correct indices are 1 and 16.

Alternatively, you can confirm the indices by inspecting the PDB file and locating the CH3 carbons in the ACE and NME groups.

Perform Stretching

Once the system is prepared, perform stretching using sith/g09_stretching/stretching.sh:

sith stretching -c -i 1,16 -m G.pdb

On 16 cores, this calculation takes ~15 minutes. On a single core, it may take ~2 hours. Our stretching process is taking place until a bond rupture occurs. The broken molecule is saved in a directory called rupture. In this case, the rupture occurred between the ACE methyl group and the rest of the molecule (Figure 3).

This tool will produce the next outcomes:

  • frozen_dofs.dat

    • First line: atoms used for stretching, marked with F (here: 1 16 F).

    • Second line: atoms involved in the rupture (here: 1 5 F).

  • Stretched structures: G-stretched<n>.<ext>

    • <n>: stretching step index (0 = unconstrained optimization).

    • <ext> includes:

      • .chk: Gaussian checkpoint file.

      • .com: Gaussian input file (with distance constraints).

      • .fchk: human-readable checkpoint file with final optimized structure.

      • .log: Gaussian log file.

      • .xyz: optimized coordinates.

  • rupture/: directory containing files for the cleaved molecule (Figure 3).

Extract Forces

With stretched structures computed, the next step is to extract the forces in a format readable by sith.

First, calculate the forces with:

sith find_forces -c -p "G-stretched" -v

This creates a forces/ directory containing G-forces<n>.<ext> files, with <ext> = com, log, chk.

Next, extract the forces into a format for sith:

sith extract_forces -c -d "forces"

This produces .fchk files, which include the necessary information for energy distribution analysis. Internally, these are generated using formchk -3 G-force<n>.chk and the corresponding Gaussian log file formatted according to sith.readers.g09_reader.

Run SITH Analysis

Now everything is ready for the actual analysis!

Load the force data and compute the energy distribution with sith:

from sith.SITH import SITH

sith = SITH('./forces')
sith.sith_analysis();

The resulting sith.SITH.SITH object stores all necessary information for further analysis.

For more details on available analysis methods, see SITH Analysis Tutorial.
